bibl.title: Letter from Harlow Brooks to S.S. Goldwater, April 6, 1935

div1.p: Brooks recommends Truby for a hospital position, describing his character and experience.

div1.head: Letter from Harlow Brooks to S.S. Goldwater, April 6, 1935
div1.opener:
HARLOW BROOKS, M.D.
47 West Ninth Street
New York
Telephone 9-1441 Stuyvesant
April 6, 1935.
Dr. S. Goldwater, Commissioner
Department of Hospitals
New York, New York
My dear Commissioner:
div1.p:
I have been informed that there is shortly likely to be a vacancy on your
staff, and that the name of General A. E. Truby, Medical Department, United States
Army, has been suggested to you. In as much as I have known Dr. Truby and his work
very well for the past seventeen years, I am presuming to tell you something of him.

In the first place he is an ideal soldier man with all the loyalty to his
chief that a successful life in the Army implies. He is a genial, hard working,
entirely reliable physician, immensely popular with his associates in the Army, and
with a host of friends, chiefly physicians, who have known him either in the Army
or in his outside contacts. He has served in the following exceedingly responsible
positions: Superintendent of the Ancon Hospital; Chief Health Officer of the Canal
Zone; four years as Chief Medical Officer, U. S. Air Service; four years as Command-
ing Officer, Letterman General Hospital, San Francisco; two years as Chief Surgeon,
Department of the Philippines; two years as Chief Surgeon at Governors Island; two
years as the Executive Officer under General Ireland, Surgeon General's Office;
from 1932 to the present time Commanding the General Medical Center, including the
Walter Reed Hospital, Washington, D. C.

General Truby was born in New York State; he is still a citizen of this
State, and throughout his entire service in the Army has looked upon New York as
his home. While he has been on duty in the neighborhood of New York he has taken
an active part in the professional life outside as well as inside the Army, and he
has stood by to promote every medical interest in the profession to such an extent
that those of us who know him--and he has a host of friends in the profession--have
grown to love him as much as we respect him and his work.

He is what is known in the Army as an “easy boss” having that rare execu-
tive ability which enables him to secure full cooperation, respect and affection
from his subordinates. He is a grand person, and I feel that his services would
be very useful to you in every way. I know that he would be welcomed most warmly
back to his own State by all the doctors who have met him.

Hoping that I am not presuming in this letter, feeling as I do that we
all have a rare opportunity to secure for our service a fine gentleman, an execu-
tive of outstanding ability, and a physician of the highest possible standard,
I am,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, HARLOW BROOKS HB:FO
